body.value: Glen Robson: So feel free to follow along on your own machines as I'm talking.
There's some kind of interactive elements to it. And there's links out to other
examples. So what I'm going to talk about today is the image API. And so we
alluded to it yesterday and Ben's presentation, he gave you a quick intro into
how the different parts of the image j API work together. And then jack in the
previous session also linked about how different parts of the image API works.
And I'm going to go into a little more depth first on how the image API works.
And then secondly, how we can use the services offer the image API to create our
own triple f image API services. So just to start off with the learning
objective, I'm hoping at the end of the day, that you get an understanding of
what the image API provides and how to use it, and be able to change the image
URL. And so you can get different parts of an image. And understand the
different types of the image j implementations. I mentioned this briefly not go
into a lot of detail. But there are different types of image API servers, some
which might be more to use case and some which might be more powerful. So I'll
talk briefly about those. And then also get some see some of the tools that work
with the image API. So you'll see with the presentation tomorrow that some of
the more advanced tools like Mirador and Universal Viewer, are based on the
presentation API, and won't work with just the image API. But we'll see some
examples of tools that do. But I'm going to start off with what is the image
API. And really start with some terminology. When I'm talking about an API
stands for application programming interface, which is a horribly complex,
complex acronym. But it basically means there's an agreed standard for the
client and the server to know what each other are doing. And so you can have a
client knows how to talk to an image server, and the image server knows exactly
what the client is going to be able to do. And that's really the basis of all
this interoperability. All the different clients know how to talk to all the
different image API servers, which makes this such a powerful tool. The second
terminology when I'm talking about a client, so this is a software which allows
you to view a trip Life Image. So a trip Life Image card, by itself be
understood by a web browser. So you usually have some sort of JavaScript that
lives in a web page, which does the conversion from the image API to something
that you can view on the web. And Examples include open seadragon, the Mirador
and Universal Viewer. And I tend to call them clients and server. So this is
software that runs on a machine somewhere, and is available all times and is
accessible over the web. So it's slightly different to a local laptop, which you
turn off and take home. A server in this context is machine that is always
available, and is always online. And the next part is the image API. So this is
the agreed standard.
Unknown: So in here, there's an image API standard. And this gives you all the
rules about using the AAA f image API, and all the different features that you
can use with the image API. And this is the thing that both the server and the
client agree on. The controls are interaction. And I'll do some highlights of
that today. And then the other thing I talked about is the image API server. And
this is the actual bit of software that you install somewhere on a server that
provides the image API. And I'll go through some examples. And we'll, we'll use
a couple of them. In the practical examples. I said, if you've got any
questions, please speak up or put it in the chat. And I'll try and work out for
them. So to start off with to start with a bit of history of how AAA started.
And so it really started out at the medieval manuscripts community. And you can
see with a lot of our early examples, and they were very much medieval
manuscript focused. But over time, there are a lot more more use cases and just
manuscripts, there's 3d objects, newspapers, paintings, pictures, a whole
variety, but it really started out of the medieval manuscript community. And
there's a great blog there from Ben who talks yesterday about what it was like
using the the old way of accessing manuscripts compared to a player from the
benefit that triple F and gives you but just to give you a personal perspective,
and also perspective from an institution who did a lot with digitization and
struggled a bit to make their stuff available online, I worked at the National
Library of Wales for 13 years, making their content available on the internet.
And when I first started, and 2005, I think the way we used to do digitization
is that we used to digitize a manuscript to the very highest quality, we could
at that time. And we come out with three different versions of the image, we'd
have a thumbnail, a reference sized image, and an archival TIFF version, which
is very high quality, but you can only access it, if you requested it from the
library, and you had a legitimate research use case. And the viewer we used was
this one, it was called a match viewer. And we were able to provide access to
the image and you'd be able to click on this little minus symbol and go to
thumbnail. But that was a limit to the interactivity, you could browse by pages,
but you couldn't ask for bigger sizes, you can ask for smaller sizes, you
couldn't assume it was just a very static website. And then as screens got
bigger, and the internet got faster, fast proves that these sort of x discovery
mechanisms wasn't enough for researchers, especially ones that wants to really
analyze the image, you can see the image here and it was a slightly bigger mess
in practice, but it was still made it very difficult to work with. And there be
no chance to run the kind of AI methods that jack was talking about in the last
session. So a lot of institutions move to a different type of access by
providing a zooming zooming service, where you could initially go to a page and
you'd see the image and then you can zoom into the area they're interested in.
And this is kind of a compromise to be able to allow access to the high quality
version, and not the archival TIFF, you'd make kind of a derivative, which was
faster on the internet and could allow this zooming function. And there are a
couple of standards around at that time. One we looked at was Zuma fi. And it
was also Microsoft had a DCI DS that I version. But these are both proprietary
file formats. So you take your TIFF you convert it into, say a DS at a file or
zoom file file. And the view is tended to be flash, which, you know, certainly
was unsupported in modern mobile viewers. And around this time as well. jpeg
2000 camera came along. I'm going to talk a bit about that later. But it was
seen as a good, relatively open format to use for these sort of zoomable
viewers.
Then enter AAA F. And the things that it really provided, that was different to
what was there before was a standard URL structure for accessing images. And
which makes it easy for us to be able to use and hack around with and but it
really makes it easier for image service to implement and viewers to be able to
consume. And it was a real change to some of the proprietary formats which were
just unreadable really for humans to be able to understand. It provides all the
information needed to drive a zooming experience. And a positive was this
hackable URLs. So you can see an example here. And Ben mentioned it yesterday.
I've simplified the version from the specifications slightly to sum up, this bit
here is the identifier for an object, followed by the region, size, rotation,
quality and format. And I'll go through each one and give a bit more
information. But you can see it's kind of a readable URL that we can understand
that we can manipulate. And because it's such a predictable URL, it also means
that it's very cacheable. So if I were to look at this image, and then we look
at it again, and so in a couple of minutes, the browser would have already
cached it. And so it wouldn't go to the server to get you a new copy. So it
means means it's a lot faster to access these images. And also means it scales a
lot better to many users. So first look at the identifier. So in this portion,
I've highlighted the identifier part of the URL. And you can see here that I've
put a few in here, and you're welcome to play with this while I'm talking. But
you can see if we switch out the identifier, the underlying image will change.
And you can see some examples from three different institutions. There. We've
got one from Harvard, we've got the DLCs, which is from digerati, which is a
commercial hosting, hosting company and services. And there was also got an
example from the Smithsonian. And you can see how they use a slightly different
but they're all in the same sort of form, where it starts with HTTPS that has
the host name, and then a path to the image. One thing to highlight is all
examples here I've used HTTPS. And that's really one important thing to improve
improve the interoperability of your images. HTTPS means that it's a secure
protocol. And if you display if you're using an HTTPS site, like For this
example, we use HTTPS here. I can only do Display HTTPS images. So that's
something to note that if you want your images to be used, you should try and
use HTTPS where possible. I've called this the identifier. And I personally
think this is kind of a identifier, the image is the full identity of fire the
image, if you put that in the browser, what you'll get to, it will forward you
on to this info dot Jason. And this info dot Jason gives you all the technical
information, you need to drive the zooming experience for that image. I'm not
going to go into a lot of detail, but you can see things like the width and the
height. And these are the width and the height of the full image, which is
hidden behind this trip last URL. And then there's this profile part here, which
tells you exactly what features the image API server that you're using supports.
And you can see them in more detail. If you follow the link to the trip Life
Image API standard. One thing to know that everything to the right of this
identifier is what's controlled by the AAA f image API. So everything after here
is predictable. And there is two options, you can either put this link into an
image, or you can get an info dot Jason. And the two things that you'll see
after this identifier. The next portion of the URL is the region. And this
allows you to select a subset or region of interest of an image. As you can see,
in this example, we've highlighted the head here. And you can see that the
format is x, y width height, with the origin at the top left. So in this
example, the X is this value here from the left, we're saying it starts at 125
pixels from the left and 15 pixels from the top. And then we're gonna go to the
width and the height, and it says it's 120 pixels wide, with 140. High. And you
can see what it comes out with. This is the kind of stuff you'd use in the URL.
But in reality, these images are so large, that it's very difficult to work out
and x, y width height. So most people use these types of cropping tools, which
will give you the information for you.
So this is an example from jack Reed. And you can see as you're moving the box
around the region part, which is this 12611030201598, that's changing as you're
changing the box. And that's much more of a common use case for people trying to
get regions it's takes a lot of mass work and guestimation to try and work it
out by hand. And this is another example from the UCD in Dublin, this is a
really great tool for picking out regions of an image.
So I've selected the head there. And if I scroll down to the bottom, you can see
the URL here, it gives you to the URL to the image and it picks out the region
for you. And there are also a couple of shortcuts. So if you put full, and that
means you want the full region of the image. So in this example, you've got the
full image, there are also square. And this is a bit of an odd one, really, but
it means that you're asking the image server to return the image as a square.
And this one is a rectangle. And the spec doesn't say how the server should do
it, it just says it should send return a square version of the image. And you
can see in this example, it chops off the head and legs. So it's not, you know,
it's it can be useful, especially for if you want square thumbnails on the page.
This can be useful. And for some images like maps, this is kind of a good
summary of what a map might be. But it doesn't work in all cases. So we've seen
the full one, which is the full sized image you see in the square. This
particular region has been picked out as the head and this particular region
focuses on the book on the hand. And you can see you can jump around the image
using this and it's the same identifier, a different region and we'll go on to
the next one's next. The next province is the size province. So again, we have
some shortcuts, like full which is the full size image. So if you were to kind
of digitize something at high quality and you'd have this TIFF version, the full
size would be the same size as that. That thing that you scanned it's the
highest quality possible version of your digitized image. Not all organizations
make their images available at full size and there are ways to restrict access
to the full size and only to smaller versions. But this example in how did they
do give you access to the full size. Another option is just to specify the
width. So this is an example with, we've just specified that it should be 500
pixels wide, we haven't specified the height and the image server is worked out.
If it's 500 pixels wide, keep the aspect ratio it needs to be so high. And
that's how you can do that. So that's a useful shorthand if you just want to
make sure it's 500 pixels wide. Because to do the opposite, where you just
specify the height. So for this example, we specified that we just want a height
it's 250. And we'll let the server work out what the width should be. Just to
give you an example, this is the same one the other way around where the width
is 250. But the height is determined by the server or the server. Or you can be
very explicit, and say I want it to fit in a 250 by 250 Square. And as you can
see, it's been distorted. So it does match the square. And if you'd rather not
distort it, you can put an exclamation mark before the number. And this says I
wanted to fit in a box of 250 by 250. But I don't want you to start it. And what
the server's done is, it's picked its longest side and made sure that that is
250. So the top is much shorter in this example. I mentioned, the full sized
image is restricted in certain institutions. And actually in version three of
the image API, we've got rid of full completely unchanged it to max. And so now
from version three onwards, you can use the max keyword and the size, and you'll
get the max allowable image which might be the full, but not necessarily if
people have restricted it.
And then rotation. So this is pretty self explanatory. And that you can rotate
the image. So this is rotated by 45 degrees. By 135. There's one slight extra
functionality is this mirroring. So if you use the exclamation mark before the
zero, it will mirror it. So that's looking at zero with the exclamation mark.
And if I take the explanation mark, you can see it's just flipped it over. Not
all servers support rotation. So we talked about this, this level of compliance,
and there are different kind of levels of advancement that each server provides.
So level zero is, is the most basic server. And it basically means that all
everything is is pre generated. There's no kind of running code that does the
image API. And so these are always the most basic requirements. And in level
zero, you don't support rotation, so you have to put the zero, you won't support
any other rotations. And then as the option support just 90 degree, this is
optional in level one and level two, two being the most comprehensive
implementation of the image API, and an arbitrary rotation. So in this example,
it does do arbitrary, because I cannot request degrees rotation, which are
different to the 90 180 and 270. And then finally, the optional of mirroring,
which this example does support and the Harvard example, and part The reason I
use used it for the demo is that it's it's a level two implementation. So it
features it implements the majority of the optional features and specification.
NET next under quality. And this is might be different to what you're expecting
with quality. And in this case, quality means the different types of color

that kind of the color it came out with when you scanned it. So you could have

Okay, so I'm going to move on to file formats. And this is just a bit of an
aside really to say that. We haven't yet mentioned file formats, or, more
specifically, we haven't mentioned the file format or the source image. And so
we saw in the previous example, that we could export it as a JPEG, PNG, and
TIFF. But we haven't made any mention of what the source format is. So this is a
format you you've digitized has come out of your digitization processes, and
you've got an image or images off the web that you'd like to use with AAA. And
the main reason for that is that AAA AF is agnostic to the source image file
file format. The AAA standard doesn't say you must use TIFF or JPEG 2000, it
says you can use any type of source image. So that decision on what source image
type to use is more related to the image server, which we're going to go into
and what they support. And almost all of them support JPEG, PNG s tests or gifs,
the kind of main common image formats, but to get the fastest experience, and
you should be using a tiled image format, and the two I've listed here are JPEG
2000, and a special kind of TIFF file called a pyramid TIFF. And what I mean by
a tiled image format is you can see this example as the Mona Lisa. And the red
squares are semones, zooming in from a thumbnail, zooming in the whole image and
then zooming into the face and then zooming into the face in more detail. And
you can see there are four different levels of zoom here. And as you're zooming,
you're seeing less and less of the full image. And this is one of the things
that makes an AAA F and some of the zooming technologies really fast and
efficient. So if you imagine this bottom image is is really a large tear for
high quality TIFF, the US there is only getting copies of the image that they're
actually viewing. And so all of these other images which are outside of your
particular viewport, and they're not being sent to the machine. And so it makes
it a very fast experience. And you're only seeing the part of the images, which
you're interested in. And triple AF can be used to address each of these
different little squares on the image. And so there's a way you can construct
the URL, as you saw with region and size and rotation and things to get access
to each of these individual squares. And these individual squares are called
tiles. And you can combine these tiles to make up an image. Now, the way JPEG
2000 and pyramid TIF works is it pre generates all of these different tiles and
all of these different levels and stores them inside the JPEG 2000 on purpose.
So that means when an image server requests this particular tile, it doesn't
need to decode the massive TIFF. It can go straight into the JPEG 2000 and pick
out the tile and send it back to the image or send it back to the user. So if
you want to make access to high quality images, and you'll see a lot better
experience, if you use JPEG 2000, or the special kind of TIFF, a pyramid, Tiff.
And a pyramid TIFF is a special kind of TIFF, it's, it's not something that will
generally come out of the digitization process. It's usually something if you
were going to use pyramid tests you you get the TIF and then you convert it from
a normal TIFF to a pyramid, Tiff. And it's a slightly unusual format. If you
have to use say, a straight PNG, for this larger image, you're basically asking
the image server to do the processing on the fly to download the full image and
the image server and then pick out the bit you're interested in throw away the
bit you're not. So it's less efficient and takes up more processing and will
generally be slower. So although triple AF doesn't mandate you having a
particular image format, the vast majority of people use JPEG 2000, or pyramid
text. And this is the reason. Are there any questions? Okay, so I'm going to
just talk about here about what the uses of the image APR image API.
